abstract.text: The base class for controls, which are visual elements that convey a specific action or intention in response to user interactions.

topicSections.title: Accessing the Controlâ€™s Targets and Actions

abstract.text: Show tooltips in your iPhone and iPad apps running on a Mac with Apple silicon, or your app built with Mac Catalyst.

inlineContent.text: Controls implement elements such as buttons and sliders, which your app can use to facilitate navigation, gather user input, or manipulate content. Controls use the target-action mechanism to report user interactions to your app.

abstract.text: Examples of UIKit controls

inlineContent.text: You do not create instances of this class directly. The

class is a subclassing point that you extend to implement custom controls. You can also subclass existing control classes to extend or modify their behaviors. For example, you might override the methods of this class to track touch events yourself or to determine when the state of the control changes.
A controlâ€™s state determines its appearance and its ability to support user interactions. Controls can be in one of several states, which the

type defines. You can change the state of a control programmatically according to your appâ€™s needs. For example, you might disable a control to prevent the user from interacting with it. User interactions can also change the state of a control.

The target-action mechanism simplifies the code that you write to use controls in your app. Instead of writing code to track touch events, you write action methods to respond to control-specific events. For example, you might write an action method that responds to changes in the value of a slider. The control handles all the work of tracking incoming touch events and determining when to call your methods.
When adding an action method to a control, you specify both the action method and an object that defines that method to the

method. (You can also configure the target and action of a control in Interface Builder.) The target object can be any object, but it is typically the view controllerâ€™s root view that contains the control. If you specify
for the target object, the control searches the responder chain for an object that defines the specified action method.
The signature of an action method takes one of three forms. The
parameter corresponds to the control that calls the action method, and the
parameter corresponds to the
object that triggered the control-related event.

abstract.text: Action method signatures

inlineContent.text: The system calls action methods when the user interacts with the control in specific ways. The

type defines the types of user interactions that a control can report and those interactions mostly correlate to specific touch events within the control. When configuring a control, you must specify which events trigger the calling of your method. For a button control, you might use the
or
event to trigger calls to your action method. For a slider, you might care only about changes to the sliderâ€™s value, so you might choose to attach your action method to
events.
When a control-specific event occurs, the control calls any associated action methods immediately. The current
object dispatches action methods and finds an appropriate object to handle the message, following the responder chain, if necessary. For more information about responders and the responder chain, see

inlineContent.text: lists the attributes for instances of the
class.
Attribute
Description
Alignment

The horizontal and vertical alignment of a controlâ€™s content. For controls that contain text or images, such as buttons and text fields, use these attributes to configure the position of that content within the controlâ€™s bounds.
These alignment options apply to the content of a control and not to the control itself. For information about how to align controls with respect to other controls and views, see
Content
The initial state of the control. Use the checkboxes to configure whether the control is in an enabled, selected, or highlighted state initially.

abstract.text: Control attributes

inlineContent.text: Because
is an abstract class, you do not internationalize it specifically. However, you do internationalize the content of subclasses like
. For information about internationalizing a specific control, see the reference for that control.

Controls are accessible by default. To be useful, an accessible user interface element must provide accurate and helpful information about its screen position, name, behavior, value, and type. This is the information VoiceOver speaks to users. Users who are blind or have low vision can rely on VoiceOver to help them use their devices.
Controls support the following accessibility attributes:
Label.
A short, localized word or phrase that succinctly describes the control or view, but does not identify the elementâ€™s type. Examples are
Add
and
Play
Traits.

A combination of one or more individual traits, each of which describes a single aspect of an elementâ€™s state, behavior, or usage. For example, you might use a combination of the Keyboard Key and the Selected traits to describe an element that behaves like a keyboard key and that is in a selected state.
Hint.
A brief, localized phrase that describes the results of an action on an element. Examples are
Adds a title
and
Opens the shopping list
Frame.
The frame of the element in screen coordinates, which the
structure specifies for an elementâ€™s screen location and size.
Value.
The current value of an element when the label doesnâ€™t represent the value. For example, the label for a slider might be
Speed
, but its current value might be
The

class provides default content for the value and frame attributes. Many controls automatically enable additional specific traits as well. You can configure other accessibility attributes programmatically or with the Identity inspector in Interface Builder.
For more information about accessibility attributes, see
Subclassing
gives you access to the built-in target-action mechanism and simplified event-handling support. You can subclass existing controls and modify their behavior in one of two ways:
Override the

method of an existing subclass to observe or modify the dispatching of action methods to the controlâ€™s associated targets. You might use this method to modify the dispatch behavior for the specified object, selector, or event.
Override the
, and

methods to track touch events occurring in the control. You can use the tracking information to perform additional actions. Always use these methods to track touch events instead of the methods that the
class defines.
If you subclass

directly, your subclass is responsible for setting up and managing your controlâ€™s visual appearance. Use the methods for tracking events to update your controlâ€™s state and to send an action when the controlâ€™s value changes.
